newsitem.title: PAKISTAN: PRESS DIGEST - Pakistan newspapers - May 23.
newsitem.headline: PRESS DIGEST - Pakistan newspapers - May 23.

text.p: These are the leading stories in the Pakistani press on Friday. Reuters has not verified these stories and does not vouch for their accuracy.
DAWN

- The Privatisation Commission has finalised strategy to privatise Karachi Electric Supply Corporation, Sui Southern Gas Company, Sui Northern Gas Company and 14 other state units in the next six months.
- The government has decided to confiscate all movable and immovable properties of defaulters to recover outstanding loans of 140 billion rupees.
- The National Assembly adopted amendments in the banking laws dissolving the Pakistan Banking Council and repealing the exclusive right of the federal government to establish a bank.
- Princess Diana has arrived in Lahore on a three-day visit to launch an endowment fund appeal for Imran Khan's cancer hospital and research centre.
- Foreign Minister Gohar Ayub Khan has said there was a possibility that Pakistani F-16 aircrafts stranded in the United States might be sold to a East European state.
- Pakistan will release all the Indian fishermen and their boats in its custody within five to 10 days.
- Pakistan's foreign exchange reserves fell to $897.76 million on May 17 from $1.094 billion on May 10 showing a big decline of $196.24 million.
BUSINESS RECORDER
- Pakistan has lost the considerable Saudi rice market to its main competitors - America, Thailand and India, a market survey conducted by the Pakistan embassy in Jeddah said.
- Finance Minister Sartaj Aziz has said the current financial year was the worst in the history of the country due to the policies of former prime minister Benazir Bhutto.

- European Commission's plan of imposing a definitive anti-dumping duty on the exports of grey fabrics from six countries including Pakistan fizzled out as majority of the member countries rejected it.
NEWS
- Flow of foreign investment in Pakistan has been dried down completely since November.
MUSLIM

- Financial irregularities to the tune of 3.1 billion rupees and $118.5 million have been detected in the budgetary allocations of defence services in the year 1994/95, said a report of Auditor General of Pakistan.
NATION
- Bhutto said the recent meeting between Nawaz Sharif and Indian Prime Minister Inder Kumar Gujral was the biggest disappointment of the present government.
- Senate passed a law prohibiting wasteful expenses at wedding ceremonies.
-- Islamabad newsroom 9251-274757
